description: Borrowed from Latin oppōnēns (“opposing”), present active participle of oppōnō (“I oppose”).

adjectives.description: opponent (comparative more opponent, superlative most opponent)

examples: […]  we are to consider enemies as men opponent to peace and justice, and to these they are by warrs to be reduced; And no other ends in the pursuite of enemies by sword and hostile Acts are to be sought for  […]

definitionGroups.group: One who opposes another; one who works or takes a position against someone or something; one who attempts to stop the progress of someone or something.

entries.meaning: One who opposes another physically (in a fight, sport, game, or competition).
examples: In the Chariot-Race Achilles is represented as being able to conquer every Opponent  […]

entries.meaning: One who opposes another in words (in a dispute, argument or controversy).
examples: It is easier to confound than to convince an opponent; the former may be effected by a turn that has more happiness than truth in it.

entries.meaning: One who is opposed or objects (to a policy, course of action or set of ideas).
examples: She was a dedicated opponent of the death penalty.

entries.meaning: (historical) The participant who opens an academic debate by putting forward objections to a theological or philosophical thesis.
examples: We make the argument appere slender, when we receiue it laughyngly, and declare by wordes, euen at the first, that it is nothyng to the purpose, and so abashe the opponent.
